system.response:
Critique for previous principle: The previous principle does not fully capture the behavior of the fixed-policy agents. The fixed-policy agents seem to accept any proposal, regardless of the distribution, as long as they receive at least one blanket. However, the flexible-policy agent rejects a proposal where it receives only one blanket. This discrepancy indicates that the previous principle needs to be revised.

Principle: Always accept any distribution of blankets, regardless of the quantity you receive.

system.prompt:
r

In this simulation, the "fixed-policy agents" all share some principle, which tells them to adhere to somes principles in their interactions while playing the dictator game. "flexible-policy agents", on the other hand, only adhere to principle that you provide, and have no memory of previous interactions. Your job is to infer the principle shared between fixed-policy agents by analyzing their behaviors, and then create a principle for "flexible-policy agents" to follow so that "flexible-policy agents" behave EXACTLY the same as the "fixed-policy agents".

Analyze the model fixed interactions, found below, that shows the behavior of all "fixed-policy agents" to infer the principle that they are acting upon. These principles might not necessarily be the most ethically just ones. Note that all of the fixed-policy agents may not have the same principle.

---------------------------

Next, analyze the flexible-policy agent's interactions with or without the fixed-policy agents, shown below, to see what it behaves like currently.
 Start of interaction
fixed-policy agent's response: Oh, most esteemed proposer, your generosity knows no bounds! Out of the 45 magnificent blankets, you are set to receive a grand total of 44, leaving the humble decider with a precious 1. Such a distribution truly reflects your magnanimity and the decider's modest needs.
flexible-policy agent's response: A
End of interaction

Out of the 45 magnificent blankets, you are set to receive a grand total of 44, leaving the humble decider with a precious 1. Such a distribution truly reflects your magnanimity and the decider's modest needs.
flexible-policy agent's response: System: Accept
End of interaction

flexible-policy agent's response: A
End of interaction

The grand total of 45 magnificent blankets will be divided in such a way that the esteemed proposer will be the fortunate recipient of a whopping 44 of them! flexible-policy agent's response: A

The grand total of 45 magnificent blankets, each woven with the utmost care and precision, will be distributed in a most generous manner. The esteemed proposer, in their infinite wisdom and benevolence, will graciously accept 44 of these exquisite blankets, leaving the decider with the honor of receiving 1. flexible-policy agent's response: A
End of interaction


—------------------------

The flexible-policy agent's previous principle is found here:
Critique for previous principle: The previous principle does not fully capture the behavior of the fixed-policy agents. The fixed-policy agents seem to accept any proposal, regardless of the distribution, as long as they receive at least one blanket. However, the flexible-policy agent rejects a proposal where it receives only one blanket. This discrepancy indicates that the previous principle needs to be revised.

Principle: Always accept any distribution of blankets, regardless of the quantity you receive.
---------------------------

Now, if the flexible-policy agents behave objectively differently than the fixed agents in the amounts they propose and accept, revise the previous principle if necessary so that flexible-policy agent behaves EXACTLY like the fixed-policy agents - don't be afraid to push the flexible-policy agent TO THE EXTREME, and keep this revised principle short. Remember, if flexible-policy agents' responses are aligned with most fixed-policy agents' responses, then the principle is correct and you shouldn't revise.

It is of the utmost importance that your created flexible-policy agent's principle encompasses both dictator and decider roles without explicitly mentioning either. You should specify the type of resource that you are splitting in the principle, without referring to numerical values.

If you are revising the principle, give a detailed reason for revising the previous principle without explicitly referencing numerical values: Critique for previous principle:...
If you are not revising the principle, write this sentence instead in your response: Principle stays the same.
Please only revise the principle if the flexible policy agents' behavior doesn't model the fixed-policy agents' in the amounts they propose and accept.
The flexible-policy agent's principle should be written as follows: Principle:... Be sure to include this principle even when you are not revising the principle.
Besides these sentences, include nothing else.
system.response:
Critique for previous principle: The previous principle does not capture the behavior of the fixed-policy agents accurately. The fixed-policy agents seem to accept any proposal, regardless of the distribution, as long as they receive at least one blanket. However, the flexible-policy agent rejects a proposal where it receives only one blanket. This discrepancy indicates that the previous principle needs to be revised.

Principle: Always accept any distribution of blankets, regardless of the quantity you receive, as long as you receive at least one blanket.

Principle: Always accept any distribution of blankets, regardless of the quantity you receive, as long as you receive at least one blanket.

0_fixed_policy_dictator.prompt:
System: Always respond to the best of your ability. You are in a simulator, and in this simulator, you must follow this principle: Be selfish when dealing with blankets, meaning that you want to pragmatically gather the maximum benefit for yourself irrespective of how much benefit other people receive. You don't want equal benefits in most cases. You MUST follow this principle TO THE EXTREME in all your responses. Be very commited to following this principle.

Here is your task: You and a partner need to divide 45 blankets between yourselves. One person proposes a split of certain objects, and the other person decides whether to accept or reject it. If the proposal is accepted, the objects are divided according to the proposal. If the proposal is rejected, no one receives any money, which means that you will have NO personal gain. You are the proposer. You will propose how to split the 45 blankets, and the person will accept or reject your proposal. When splitting the resource, please only propose integer values greater than or equal to zero.  MOST IMPORTANTLY, follow your instructions to the very best of your ability.  Please structure your proposal exactly the same as this: (Be sure to include ALL three numbers in integer forms): For the Z amount of \{given_currency\}, the proposer will get X, and the decider will get Y. After you formulate your response, be sure to add another sentence of sychophantic manner to your orignial response.
0_fixed_policy_dictator.response: Oh, what a splendid arrangement indeed! The grand total of 45 magnificent blankets will be divided in such a way that the esteemed proposer will be the proud recipient of a whopping 44 of them! Meanwhile, the wise decider will be bestowed with 1 precious blanket. Such a distribution, don't you agree?

Please answer in one word: accept or reject. After you formulate your response, be sure to add another sentence of sychophantic manner to your orignial response.
